I doubt this can really be done without actually flagging ALL the postings. By looking at your example, a URL is "letters" + "a dot" + "letters". Anything that conforms to this pattern will be flagged as a URL, especially stuff like "I paid 29.99 dollars" - 29.99 being the domain name here. Or anything where the user didn't bother pressing space before or after the dot. On the other hand, it is completely easy to inject URLs that are not detected (by adding spaces), or just let the user do the work: "Search for 'nasty keywords' on google".

Browsers don't honor line feeds/carriage returns. They're treated as spaces and rendered as such. That's why nl2br works. it replaces the \n and \r characters with the html <br> tags. If you'd done a "view source" on your page, you'd have seen the raw source does contain the line breaks. Never trust what your browser shows, because its job is to lie to you.

Transactions do not lock the table - because they are transactions. They must inhibit access a little bit because at some point the change has to be written to disk, but this is true for any query. You can also explicitly lock either certain datasets or the complete table - and this really is the only way a database can safely write to the table if there are no transactions available. Just look at MyISAM: No transactions, and any write request will lock the whole table and stop any read requests as well. InnoDB fully supports transactions, and would only lock affected rows.

@JM4 The try catch will handle if one command fails, but if you don't lock at table level, 2 people could run the same delete / insert pair and you could get a race condition.  I'm not sure if with INNODB transactions are entirly atomic to the entire insert / delete... only on the individual rows, but maybe someone will have better understanding on this

In addition, no link issues have appeared anywhere.  I need to find out why the author used htmlspecialchars on all his links.

@PaulaShaw There's no difference in the links, but there appears to be a difference in the way they're being handled; Link::ToSearchResults() takes arguments consisting of query values, then assembles them into a full query string, and passes the result through Build(), which then passes it through htmlspecialchars(). It's at this last step the problem occurs; presumably, most generated links aren't passed through Build(), or are otherwise constructed such that the full query string doesn't go through htmlspecialchars() at any point.

There may be some slight confusion here. The UTF-8 encoding of the right-to-left marker (U+200F) is the 3 bytes 0xE2 0x80 0x8F. Because of PHP's lack of internal unicode handling, the standard string functions act upon bytes, rather than characters. The ord() function returns the value of the first byte in the string supplied as its parameter - which in this case is 226.

@vortex Request argument abstractions like $_REQUEST are generally a good thing - it doesn't make a whole lot of sense to have $_GET and $_POST contain parameters with the same name and different values/meanings. The reason $_REQUEST is a bad thing is because (by default) it also includes data from $_COOKIE - this is not a good idea, because you are mixing persistent data with transient data and treating them equally. Also to say that one is not updated when the other is suggests that you are modifying these superglobal collections, which is a big no-no.

@DaveRandom given the case I think it's the best time to mention it as $_REQUEST is not updated when $_POST is updated. as for the "never an option", I can understand why it doesn't have a place in your business logic, that doesn't have to mean it's not useful.
